title: Beauty and the Beast's Luke Evans drops debut single Love Is a Battlefield
text:
Surprise – Luke Evans his dropped his debut single!

And it’s not quite as random as it seems, either: the star was in fact trained by Charlotte Church’s singing coach back in the day!

The Beauty and the Beast actor’s first foray into pop stardom is the song Love Is a Battlefield, out now – and naturally, it has a moody black and white video to match.

It’s the first track from Luke’s upcoming debut album At Last, out 22 November.

An orchestral version of a song by Pat Benatar, other covers on the album include U2’s With Or Without You and classic Etta James song At Last.

Luke Evans is looking suitably smoldering as he launches his new material (Picture: BMG)

In a statement, Luke said of the release: ‘The album is a reimagining of very well-known tracks. So we were looking for tracks that we could strip right back down to the bare essentials and then add new arrangements.

‘Turning an 80s pop anthem or power ballad into something more acoustic or intimate – but retaining the essence of the original.’

Die-hard fans will know Luke has previously sang in his 00s stage roles, for the likes of Avenue Q and Boy George biopic Taboo.

He told Wales Online back in 2010: ‘When I was growing up, I loved to sing. I used to be taught by Louise Ryan, Charlotte Church’s singing coach, which is why I wanted to go into musicals.’

The Hobbit actor Luke in his new music video (Picture: BMG)

Fans on Instagram heaped praise on the Welsh star’s efforts, with one saying: ‘Don’t lose your accent – be like Tom [Jones]’ while another called the song ‘a fairy tale for the soul and a pleasure for the heart.’

Best-known as an actor, Luke’s screen credits include Dracula Untold and The Girl On the Train.

Earlier this year, Luke opened up about his mental health self-care routine.

Speaking on Lorraine, he said: ‘Being mentally aware of your well-being psychologically is important.

‘We all carry baggage around with us. Men carry it way deeper than women most of the time. We’re not good at talking about it and opening up.

‘I was talking about therapy and how important it is, if you have it, to have it. Sometimes you forget what you’re carrying around on a daily basis and it stores itself and builds up.’
